awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Enzyme-Powered, Programmable Active Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:
Imagine a world in which roads can sense their damage and repair themselves like human skin, or in which natural disasters such as forest fires and landslides are prevented by materials that change shape and stiffness automatically, or in which clothing materials change their porosity to become personal protective equipment (PPE) when the clothing itself senses airborne pathogens. These futuristic ideas are currently science fiction, but if we have any hope of creating these amazing technologies, we need to begin today. This collaborative project seeks to explore the fundamental underpinnings of the materials needed for such applications. Specifically, in order to design any of these futuristic devices, we need to have materials that are self-powered and assembled hierarchically from energy-using building blocks. Luckily, many biological systems, such as cells, plants, and humans, are already capable of sensing their environment and responding by moving, changing shape, or releasing chemicals. The basic building blocks of these biological “systems” are enzymes, nanoscale machines made of protein that come in a variety of shapes and sizes. In order to dissect and begin to create an understanding of how enzymes can animate matter, our team will use enzymes to power new synthetic materials at the nanoscale to microscale. In the future, these nanoscale materials can be assembled themselves to create new larger scale active materials. 

Technical Abstract:
The scientific objective of this project is to understand the physics of synthetic active materials powered by enzymes. The research team combines expertise in DNA nanotechnology, enzyme kinetics, single-particle tracking, and sensitive force measurements to address the following objectives: (1) The team uses DNA origami to design, create, and characterize a suite of active particles, driven by enzyme catalysis, with programmable size, shape, flexibility, and location of propulsive enzymes. This objective addresses a need to create new nano- to mesoscale active particles and uses these particles to understand the mechanisms governing enhanced motility. (2) The team characterizes the properties of an active bath of enzyme-driven particles via the fluctuation spectrum, dissipation of energy, and the ability of an active bath to propel passive particles to extract work from noise. A combined study of the single-particle motility and the active fluctuations that emerge from collections of active particles will reveal a wealth of new information, including the mechanisms of enhanced transport of active particles, as well as a non-equilibrium statistical mechanical description of active fluctuations. The importance of this approach lies in the potential to specify the microscopic details of active particles, like their size, shape, and flexibility, and then to discover how these attributes alter the single-particle and collective behaviors.

This DMR grant supports research to understand the physics of synthetic active materials powered by enzymes with funding from the Condensed Matter Physics (CMP) and Biomaterials (BMAT) Programs in the Division of Materials Research of the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

The overarching scientific objective of this project was to understand the physics of synthetic active materials powered by enzymes. To this end, we completed two interrelated studies. In Study 1, we developed a new materials platform that combined DNA origami and protein enzymes. In particular, we developed new bioconjugation schemes to site-specifically label nanometer-scale colloidal particles with protein enzymes without altering the enzymatic activity. Then, to understand the role of enzyme activity on the motility of enzymes and enzyme-bound nanostructures, we utilized total internal reflection microscopy and single-particle tracking to characterize the motion of DNA-origami nanoparticles labeled with specific numbers of enzymes at site-specific locations.  Publications of the results of these studies are forthcoming. Going forward, these studies may help to shed light on the mechanisms underlying enhanced diffusion of enzymes in the presence of their substrate or other small molecules undergoing chemical reactions. In Study 2, we characterized the properties of active baths of enzymes or bacteria via their fluctuation spectra, dissipation of energy, and their ability to propel passive particles to extract work from noise. Specifically, we used optical tweezers to quantify the force fluctuations of passive colloidal particles in active baths, as well as enzyme-labeled colloidal particles in passive baths. For the case of a passive particle in an active bath of bacteria, we found a diversity of behaviors that depended on the Peclet number, a measure of the relative importance of advection to diffusion, including enhanced force fluctuations and shear thickening. Additional publications from this study are forthcoming. Ultimately, we anticipate that the results from this study could help to constrain the development of new theories of non-equilibrium thermodynamics. 

 

Broader Impacts:

The scientific outcomes of this project could impact fields ranging from materials science and soft condensed matter physics to cell biology. In addition to advances in technology and basic science, this project also created a number of unique opportunities focused on undergraduate and graduate education. We developed and ran annual summer workshops that took advantage of the complementary expertise of the research investigators to support students from the collaboration. We also developed a student exchange program that created opportunities for undergraduates from our institutions to spend the summer in another lab within the collaboration. The project supported the training of eight graduate students and nine undergraduate students in the interdisciplinary field of soft-matter physics. To date, all of the trainees who have graduated have remained in the STEM workforce, including four students who have gone on to PhD programs in related disciplines. One of the publications from this project has undergraduate students as co-authors. Five masters students completed their terminal master's degrees and one PhD student completed their dissertation and is pursuing a postdoctoral fellowship.


Last Modified: 10/31/2024
Modified by: William B Rogers
